definitions.definition: the place believed to be the home of devils and where bad people go after death

examples.text: He was terrified of **going to hell** when he died.
They were threatened with spending eternity in hell.
Lava poured out of the volcano, glowing like the fires of hell.
tormented souls in hell

definitions.definition: a very unpleasant experience or situation in which people suffer very much
definitions.sensetop: in hellhell for somebodyit is hell doing something

examples.text: The last three months have been hell.
He **went through hell** during the trial.
Her parents **made her life hell**.
Being totally alone is my idea of **hell on earth**.
He was in a hell of his own making.
For the last few weeks my whole family has been in hell because of this.
Since she moved in, life has been hell for the other residents.
It was hell getting through airport security.
I'm never going to escape this hell.
It was sheer hell having to sit through hours of boring lectures!

definitions.definition: a swear word that some people use when they are annoyed or surprised or to emphasize something. Its use is offensive to some people.

examples.text: Oh hell, I've burned the pan.
What the hell do you think you are doing?
Go to hell!
I can't really afford it, but, what the hell *(= it doesn't matter)*, I'll get it anyway.
He's as guilty as hell.
‘Do you understand?’ ‘Hell, no. I don't.’

definitions.definition: suddenly there was a lot of noise, arguing, fighting, etc.

examples.text: There was a loud bang and then all hell broke loose.

definitions.definition: to hit somebody/something very hard

examples.text: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

definitions.definition: to annoy somebody very much

examples.text: The song just bugs the hell out of me.

definitions.definition: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something

examples.text: If your dad finds out you'll really catch hell!

definitions.definition: a lot of trouble

examples.text: There'll be hell to pay when he finds out.

definitions.definition: just for fun; for no real reason

examples.text: They stole the car just for the hell of it.

definitions.definition: used to describe a very unpleasant person or thing; the worst that you can imagine

examples.text: They are the neighbours from hell.
It really was the holiday from hell—it rained all the time, we all got colds, and we missed the plane home.
She's the girlfriend from hell—I don't know why he puts up with her.

definitions.definition: to leave a place very quickly

examples.text: Let's get the hell out of here.

definitions.definition: to make life unpleasant for somebody

examples.text: He used to give his mother hell when he was a teenager.
My new shoes are giving me hell *(= are hurting me)*.

definitions.definition: to shout at or speak angrily to somebody

examples.text: Dad will give us hell when he sees that mess.

definitions.definition: to get into a very bad state

examples.text: This firm's gone to hell in a handbasket since the new management took over.

definitions.definition: as quickly as possible

examples.text: to ride hell for leather

definitions.definition: used to refer to somebody, usually a woman, who has reacted very angrily to something, especially the fact that her husband or partner has been unfaithful
used to give emphasis to what a person is saying

examples.text: The firm was in a hell of a mess when he took over.
This holiday is going to cost a hell of a lot of money.
It must have been one hell of a party.
It’s taken him a hell of a long time to get here.
That's one helluva big house you've got.

definitions.definition: despite any difficulties

examples.text: I was determined to go, come hell or high water.

definitions.definition: used to express anger or surprise

examples.text: Hell’s teeth, I promised I’d be back by two.

definitions.definition: very fast

examples.text: She was driving like a bat out of hell.

definitions.definition: used for emphasis

examples.text: She worked like hell for her exams.
My broken finger hurt like hell.

definitions.definition: used when you are refusing permission or saying that something is not true

examples.text: ‘I'm coming with you.’ ‘Like hell you are *(= you certainly are not)*.’

definitions.definition: to have no chance at all
to have no chance at all

examples.text: She doesn't have a hope of winning.
You don't have a hope in hell of finding a job.

definitions.definition: to have no chance at all

examples.text: There isn't a snowball's chance in hell that I'll wear that thing!

definitions.definition: to affect something/somebody badly

examples.text: Driving on these rough roads has played hell with my tyres.

definitions.definition: to protest angrily, especially in a way that causes trouble for somebody
it is not enough to intend to do good things; you must actually do them
to frighten, annoy, etc. somebody very much
used to say that somebody has been through a difficult situation

examples.text: We'd been to hell and back together and we were still good friends.

definitions.definition: used to express anger or dislike and to say that you no longer care about somebody/something and will take no notice of them

examples.text: ‘To hell with him,’ she thought, ‘I'm leaving.’

wordOrigin: Old English hel, hell, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hel and German Hölle, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘to cover or hide’.
